Two Poems From The War 

By Lieutenant G.A. Tinnepower, 1st Lincolnshire Regiment (Territorial Force).

These two poems are interesting because they give a feel for the conditions of the front line, but also because they are so matter-of-fact. There is little of the usual sentimentality of poems about war, and none of the jingoism.

The first poem, "Nobody Wonders" struck me immediately as being evocative of the front line experience, but says it in a very matter-of-fact way. There is no self-pity, or longing, or sense of injustice - just a bald statement of fact. And of course, that is how the soldiers wanted it to be. They did not want to be remembered as victims, but as survivors.

The second poem, "It's A Queer Time" is not so much a poem about the war, as a poem about the effect of the war on the poet. Again, there is little emotion shown, but the message is clear enough. War makes people numb to death, and hence to life. Ironically, it is only by experiencing death that we can fully appreciate life.

Nobody wonders, nobody cares,
If we go over the top tomorrow,
Or if anything else happens to us.

If we are killed, well, that's how it is;
And if we aren't, well, that's how it is.

If we are wounded, we shan't be able to drink beer,
And if we aren't, we'll jolly well drink it.

It's a funny sort of war, anyhow.

Nobody ever worries about me,
If I'm in any danger, or discomfort,
Or if I have got dysentery,
Or if my nerves are a bit dicky;
If I go 'long with it, that's how it is;
And if I don't, well, that's how it is.

It's a funny sort of war, ain't it?

Nobody wonders why we went in;
If we had taken Germany's offer,
Which was undoubtedly a good one,
We might have been home by now.
But we did not, so here we are -
There's no sense in getting glum.

It's a queer time, everybody says,
But when you've been here a while,
You sort of wonder

Learned Helplessness Sympathy Syndrome 

We don't know how to fix this. 

We shuffle around the edges; 

sizing up the catastrophe, 

trying not to drown in the onslaught of details, 

drown in the inundation of information, 

in the sentimental sludge of other people's tears, 

other people's trauma, 

other people's tragedies. 

There is nothing useful to do. 

There is nothing _we_ can do. 

We were never invited here. 

These are not our ashes to sweep up. 

These are not our toys to pick up. 

These are not our bodies to drag from rubble. 

Offer your condolences.

Offer your tears.

Offer your ideas, 

then leave the rubble to the people who live there, 

to the people whose misery is their home. 

This is not our tragedy. 

We are lucky we get to go home.

By the cold hearth, and marked the withered flower
Amid the desolate home?
Hast thou not marked the widow, worn and old,
Go mourning to the grave, with her last boy,
And weep as she lays down the dearest thing
That Heaven has left her, with a breaking heart?
And then thou hast forgotten all; for thou
Hast heard the name of the good man brought up
With a sort of reverence, as if it were
A name well worthy to be numbered
With the names of great men.
And then thou hast looked to the selfsame spot,
And, lo! the sod is unaccustomed to
The weight of a good man's grave.
And all around thou hast seen the evil that
Men do still flourishing, like a green bay tree,
And perilous it is to venture nigh,
For the fatal branches are so closely intertwined
That the unwary stranger is by the poison deceived.

She'd stand in the meadow,
In the setting sunlight,
Entirely perfect,
Wheeling her arms in the air;
And if I were with her,
That would be enough;
And if I were with her,
That would be happiness.
All of the clattering organs
Would stop, and the world would be
Adequate, and the church
Would disappear in the sky,
If I were with her,
And she were with me.
Then the noises would start again;
The dogs would begin to yelp,
And the church would sink back through the clouds,
And she would change,
Or I would see her as she is,
And that would be worse;
For all of the things that I had felt
While my senses were under spell
Would become bearable,
Quantifiable,
I would want to be
Where I ought to be
If I were with her;
And not only as
She is, but as she
Appears to me:
For all of the things that I know
Would become clear, and the world
Would accommodate
If I could see her
As she is
And not as she
Appears to me.

how often he changed his drink,
how his eyes never left the door,
how he whispered to his beer

how the rain soaked
his worn out boots,
how the seams were splitting,
how he seemed to sink
with every step,
how his breath smelled
of winter branches
and damp earth,
how his fingers
were tangled with mine
only long enough
to count my pulse,
how he turned to leave
but hesitated,
how he said my name
under his breath
and disappeared
like a shadow in the night?

That which shines on the mountain-top,
Shines on the valley-low;
Where the strength of the wild tornado-blast
Has swept the forest-foliage brown,

Shines in the secret nook:

To tell his daughter how the wood-bine twines,
And the violet grows.

This—the Spirit of Poetry—doth wear

"The Evil Seekers" was the first of his 'lost' poetry and was discovered in 1922 by The Black Prince in a volume called Poems by Various Writers. His poem is based on "The Evil Queen" in a short story by Lord Byron. The poet used three images--the woman as a thief, the woman and the bird, and the man as a thief--and used a language that is somewhat reminiscent of an ironic English verse."

The poem concludes with a warning of the dangers of "sinners",

"But what is it, that we think in sin? It is not the lust of a man which makes evil in his heart, it is his ignorance. A man in his own power may do good: for our power lies in God that gives us power over sin."

The poem "The Evil Seekers" is part of what is known as Keats' "lost" poetry. Keats believed that the poems could be recovered after his death (according to Keats biographer Charles Burney), which raises some interesting questions. How did Keats know that in 1921 he had lost the poem? Was Keats trying to recast the mystery behind his poem to his admirers (as the black prince claimed that Keats had attempted to do to his poem), or did he just have a strong sense of the poem, and believed without a doubt that his poem would be found one day? It's a bit of a conundrum, but one that we as modern poets must learn to handle. Keats was an exceptionally prolific writer, as the above quote attests.

In March, 1855 Mark Twain wrote the ballad "Balls Of Fire" in the town square at Westport, Connecticut, during a visit from his friend and fellow satirist John Ruskin. Ruskin was well known for taking satirical liberties with the truth in his letters to the editor. A year earlier, Twain and Dr. Horace Greeley had collaborated to publish the satirical travel and travel guide "Life Among the Chaldaeans", an account of life among the inhabitants of the northernmost part of Iran. But their collaboration had resulted in what became one of the most discussed incidents in modern history-the attack by a drunken sailor who had landed in the town of Westport, Rhode Island, and, having been informed that the town was inhabited entirely by chaldaeans, had killed forty-six men and raped ten women, among them "Hazel". Twain was aghast. "The best thing we can do to teach them to stay away from us will be to drive them into a hole if we can do so," he wrote. The verse was a plea for action against the criminal. "You can't drive them out forever/No/We can't do that/And neither can you/No/And it won't do to fight it in the streets," Twain wrote, going on to warn that the residents of Rhode Island have "a history of lynching blacks".

One of the reasons many of us have trouble with the concept of eternal life is not because we think, I can't imagine living forever. That's the least of our problems. The reason we get into trouble is, _I can't imagine the Lord ever loving me enough to want to keep me for eternity_.

What a terrible conclusion that is! We may love the Lord as our Savior, but we can't think that he would love us enough to offer us a life after death. But even that is not the worst of it.

In the first chapter we looked at a statement that was made by Jesus: "I am come that ye might have life, and that ye might have it more abundantly" (John 10:10). Think again on what this really means.

To you who never quite caught on to the Lord's plan, we want to say, _Think_! What more can a man ask for, what greater glory, than to be self-reliant?
When a man can no longer live without certain things he must know where to get them, and that's what I mean by self-reliance. You don't just stay on a ship if you see it's going to sink; you save yourself in another way. But self-reliance is not just to save your own self, it's also a way of living. You don't try to blame others, you don't try to depend on others, you rely on yourself.
We don't live to be free in America but, in actual fact, we live without freedom, we live in a state of servitude. But there are still enough men who can say "I live in freedom." You see, there are still some who aren't fooled by their own servility! This is why I call you my friend who knows the truth! Because you've found out that without freedom there is no joy in life, nor is joy possible with slavery.
The greatest thing we can do for ourselves is to live a truly human life, however insignificant that life may be; to know where the sun rises and where it sets, and to accept the reality that we have to rise each day and work and then each day die; to accept our fate as human beings, neither angels nor beasts, but men; to accept the truth that we are born, we live, and we die. There are few of us who know this simple truth.
The meaning of our life is in the living, not in the dying, and if we truly believe it we would live in a way different from our present way of living. We would live our lives more happily and more truthfully; we would live in a spiritual sense, and death would no longer be considered the end!

The poet, Robert Penn Warren is regarded as one of the foremost southern writers in American literature, both as critic and as novelist. He was born on April 5, 1905, in Guthrie, Kentucky and died on July 7, 1989 in Lexington, Kentucky. Warren received a Bachelor of Arts and a Master of Arts at Vanderbilt University in 1926 and 1927 respectively. At Harvard University, he earned an M.A. Degree in English, in 1929, and the Ph.D., in 1931. Thereafter, he was lecturer in Yale from 1932 to 1934 and professor of English in Vanderbilt University from 1934 to 1949. At Smith College, Warren held the Charles C. Tillinghast Professorship of English from 1949 to 1966; he was the Sterling Professor of English in Yale from 1966 to 1981. He was President of the National Institute of Arts and Letters from 1959 to 1960 and the American Academy of Arts and Letters from 1966 to 1977. Warren's literary awards include the Pulitzer Prize, a Guggenheim Fellowship and the National Book Award.
Warren's writing interests include fiction, plays, essays and poetry. His other important writings to refer to include the "Brother" (1947) and "World Ends" (1951) novels. His numerous short stories were collected into the novels titled "Once and forever" (1974) and "The Fables Of Faubus" (1976). He has published a critical work titled "Selected Essays" (1977) and "Collected Stories" (1990). His plays which were staged by the New York Shakespeare Festival and by leading European companies include "The Great Gatsby" (adaptation), "Night Rider" (1951) and "Camino Real" (1953).

The Unknown Soldier | by Lawrence Ferlinghetti
He has one more cigarette and then
It's off to the movies and
Onto the streets for the
Newspaper with the scores of the
Football games and the
Results of the balloting
And the political scandals and
The stock market and all the rest
But this one night he cannot
Get there. The lights of the
Movie houses, the juke boxes,
The little red dots of the
Burger places, shine on the
Dark streets and are more
Lively than the bars where the
Old men sit. But he has one
More cigarette then he moves
To the door with his small
Tired body and he moves
On a pair of worn shoes for the
Thirst and the lights and the
Tired boys and girls of the
Loud bars and the movie
Screens that flicker through
The streets. He has one
More cigarette and he
Hurries down to the
Lonely streets where the red
Dots of the bars shine in the
Streets.
This poem may not have the literary merit of a poem of e. e. cummings, Dylan Thomas, or T. S. Eliot, but it does have merit. The reader is taken on a short journey with the unknown soldier. They encounter him, and in effect, become him, on a cigarette-and-cigar journey into the night, with its loneliness, bars, girls, sports scores, and political scandals.
The reader is led to believe that the unknown soldier is just someone like themselves, a regular guy sitting in his apartment waiting for the big game. However, the reader then realizes that this is, in fact, a lonely soldier looking for excitement, wanting a night out. The short lines, which almost have an iambic rhythm, seem to move the soldier along, as well as the reader. Perhaps no one poem can capture what war or the soldier is all about; however, this poem is a strong start.
